Award.AwardTitle: Excitation Transport and Coherence in Nano-Plasmonic Wire Materials by Experiment and Simulation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) program of the Division of Chemistry will support the research program of Prof. Norbert Scherer of the University of Chicago. Prof. Scherer and his students will investigate how light could be used to control the plasmonic behavior of metallic nanowire systems. Combining theoretical work and simulations with spectroscopic measurements, the team of investigators will strive to achieve coherent control of plasmon propagation in nanowires and nanowire interferometers, and to create delocalized excitons by coupling quantum dots with silver nanowires.

The resulting new plasmonic-coupled materials will advance fundamental ideas for sensing, information and energy transport, computing and perhaps (solar) energy harvesting. The integrated program could lead to new functions of nanomaterials, such as nanolensing and excitonic coupling over long distances, and to the development of linear and nonlinear optical nanoscale circuits. The experimental, theoretical and intellectual challenges of the proposed research will provide a rich environment for graduate student and postdoctoral training in nanoscience and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research supported by this grant was fundamental in nature but it has many interesting and intuitive appealing aspects. The basic question that was addressed in this research was to discover new ways to manipulate nanoparticles using light. The motivation is that by arranging a varity of different types of metal and semiconductor nanoparticles on surfaces or in solution that one could create circuits for optical computing or have reconfigurable transducers for sensing various types of biological and other types of substances. To do this one needs to understand and quantify the rules and the forces that can be brought to bare on nanoparticle manipulation. As opposed to atom trapping that is done in vacuum and at exceedingly low temperature, the intended applications occur in solution (typically water) and at or near room temperature. Therefore, the tiny, sub-microscopic particles, necessarily are pushed and kicked by the solvent and undergo ubiquitous movement known as Brownian motion. Since the energy figure of merit of the random forces in solution is kT (Boltzmann's constant times the temperature), the forces to trap and hold particles must be of this magnitude or larger. Moreover, our goal was not just to trap and manipule the particles deterministically, but to have them self-organize into predictable structures either in solution or at surfaces. Therefore, the research was concerned with understanding what optical forces could be brought to bare, how the particles interact with each other in the presence of an applied (external) optical (electromagnetic) field - that is with light. 

We discovered a new class of material, optical matter, that is built by allowing the light interacting with one nanoparticle to also influence it neighbors and then to cause them to organize into various arrangements. An example of these particle arrangements is shown in a figure that illustrates a range of stable structures that could be controllably and reproducably formed. Some of these particle arragements could also be pattered in a self-organizational manner on chemically functionalized surfaces (e.g. on glass). The experimental studies were complemented by computer simulations that explicitly solve the matter-light interaction for various particle numbers and other bounding conditions, such as the shape of the focused light field that is applied the the solution containing the metal (and other) nanoparticles. Still, eventhough one can do the computation, one needs to experiment to define reality and realistic conditions. Moreover, the simulations could only deal with static configurations and not the actual dynamics and Brownian motion (noise) that is present - the simulations need to be done collaboratively with experiment so that one guides and informs the other.

We expect that in the near future we will be able to make more complex structures that would integrate light absorbing and emitting elements into the now well controlled metal nanoparticle arrays that would allow optical sensing (detection) and would also allow exploring possible nonlinear interactions that these materials can have. A nonlinearity is requred if one is to have a capability for optical computation. the present grant and research has laid an important part of the intellectual and methodological basis for developing this capability.
